Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the strength of the United States economy, stating that it was "the greatest economy in the history of our country," which is contradicted by experts who argue that it was strong but not the best in history.
Understate: The claim understates the growth in gross domestic product (GDP) achieved under previous presidents and the mediocre performance of metrics such as wages and business investment during the period before the pandemic.
Falters at times: The claim falters in acknowledging that the growth in GDP under Trump was well below his pledge of 4% and lower than that of prior presidents.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to substantiate its assertion of having the greatest economy in history, as economists provide evidence that contradicts this claim.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the strength of the U.S. economy before the pandemic can be solely attributed to President Trump, while experts argue that he benefited from trends that were already in place during the Obama recovery.
Exist alternative explanation: Experts offer an alternative explanation, suggesting that the strength of the economy under Trump is more of an Obama story than a Trump story, comparing it to a relief pitcher boasting about winning the game with a seven-run lead.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the growth in GDP under Trump was similar to that of the final six years under his predecessor, Barack Obama, and well below that of previous presidents.
